pullRequest.title: [Issue 2037] Limit hot blocks in memory (with race condition fix)
pullRequest.bodyText:
PR Description
Limit hot blocks kept in memory.
This PR reapplies reverted changes from  #2211 with an additional fix for a race condition. The following example scenario illustrates the race condition:

Transaction A adds a block.
Transaction A is committed and we pre-calculate changes to be applied.

These changes included a new blockTree containing the newly added block.


Then, transaction B starts (updating something irrelevant to the chain data like time).
Transaction B commits, and pre-calculates its changes.

These pre-calculations are based on the existing data in Store which does not contain the pending changes from Transaction A.  So, the updated blockTree calculated here does not contain the new block from Transaction A.


Transaction A finishes committing, applying the new blockTree with its new block.
Transaction B finishes committing, overwriting the blockTree with its version which is missing the new block from Transaction A.  Now, the new block is no longer tracked.

The fix is to only calculate and apply blockTree updates when the tree is actually modified (new blocks are added or a new finalized root is set).  Because all block updates are synchronized, we won't encounter this race condition.
Fixed Issue(s)
Fixes #2037
Documentation

 I thought about documentation and added the documentation label to this PR if updates are required.

commit.message:
Revert "Revert "[Issue 2037] Limit hot blocks kept in memory (#2211)" (#2240)"

This reverts commit 50fa4ed6a34761f2c2c9d9d97621e41b7c05266f.

Fix race condition - only update blockTree when necessary

This prevents transactions irrelevant to the blockTree structure from
overwriting blockTree updates.

nodes.bodyText: Would be good to include as much information in this exception message as possible - it proved quite hard to understand when it was popping up a lot last time.  Ideally it would be good to start and end slots we were trying to load blocks for and the block root of the state we were trying to regenerate.
We probably shouldn't modify the list that's passed in by sorting it.  That said, we never seem to actually run this code so maybe just remove it?

nit: It may be worth logging an issue to tidy up the future handling then make all these TODO comments reference that issue number so they're easier to find (e.g. `// TODO(#xxxx) - handle future properly)

Should we have a version of this that commits an update to time (or anything else that doesn't affect the block tree) before the transaction applies?  Basically covering the race condition case we had previously.  Sorry if I missed it somewhere.
